developing new anti-HIV agents which can be used for prevention of HIV/AIDS dissemination. natural antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are widely expressed and rapidly induced on epithelial surfaces to repel invasion from diverse infectious agents including bacteria, viruses, fungi and parasites. most AMPs maintain certain common features such as being small (10–50 amino acids) Scorpion venom is a cocktail of peptides and proteins with diverse bioactivities. five scorpion venom peptides and their derivatives were screened for their anti-HIV-1 activities. three of them (mocroporin-M1, BmKn2 and Kn2-7) showed potent anti-HIV-1 activity, in which Kn2-7 showed the highest level of anti-HIV-1 activity. we speculated that Kn2-7 might be a potential lead peptide. information of mucroporin, Kn2-7 was modified from BmKn2 by enhancing the net positive charge of the hydrophilic side and the amphiphilic helix through amino acid replacing (G3K, A4R, and S10R) we found Kn2-7 had higher anti-HIV-1 activity than BmKn2 but with similar CC50 to cells and even decreased toxicity response by the mouse skin model test. Kn2-7 was proven to be active to both cell-free and cell-associated replication-competent HIV-1 exhibited by its suppressing capability on infected TZM-bl cells. 15 g/ml of Kn2-7 almost completely inhibited viral replication-competent HIV-1. we assumed that Kn2-7 may implement the inhibition of HIV-1 with the similar mechanism. a rationally designed peptide, Kn2-7, shows potent antiviral activities against 13 strains of HIV-1 subtype B strains by direct interaction with virus regardless of their tropism with low cytotoxicity. the data presented here suggest that Kn2-7 is a potential microbicide candidate against HIV-1 and even become a powerful anti-HIV-1 drug component when it is conjugated with HIV-1 specific antibodies. mucroporin-M1 is an 11-amino peptide by removing 6 N-terminal amino acids from mucroporin as a control in this study. all peptides were purified on a C18 column (Elite HPLC, China) using a linear gradient and peaks were detected by the absorbance at 215 nm. TZM-bl, 293 T and Vero cells were cultured in modified Eagle's medium. the cells were incubated at 37°C in a humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO2. the 50% tissue culture infectious dose (TCID50) measurements were done in triplicates using 8 serial four-fold dilutions of each HIV-1 PV. each well of a 96-well culture plate was added with 100 l diluted PV firstly and then with trypsinized TZM-bl cells. plates were incubated at 37°C in a humidified, 5% CO2 atmosphere for 48 h. an HIV-1 subtype B, X4-tropic proviral DNA (pKS242 molecular clone) [55] was used to produce replication-competent virus by transfecting Vero cells with Lipo2000 agent. virus was propagated in CEM174 cells and supernatant were collected. the absorbance was measured at 490 nm using an ELISA plate reader. the relative cell viability (%) related to control wells containing cell culture medium without peptide was calculated by [A] test/[A] control100%. from 0.25 g/ml to 30 g/ml were used in time-dependent effect experiment. peptides were incubated with 200 TCID50 of HIV-1 PV for 3 min, 10 min, 30 min, 60 min, and 90 min respectively. dilutions of peptide (5 g/ml, 10 g/ml, and 15 g/ml) were incubated for 1 h at 37°C. TZM-bl cells were infected with mixture of HIV-1 PV and 10 g/ml peptides pre-incubating at 37°C for 1 h. a double antibody sandwich ELISA was used for p24 protein detection. the reaction was stopped with 1 M H2SO4, and the plate was read at 450 nm and 570 nm. the linear range was from 5 pg/ml to 100 pg/ml. the p24 concentration of the sample was computed using the equation. data analysis The virus titer was calculated within each individual experiment using the method of Reed and Muench. data were presented as one representative of at least three repeated experiments. data were presented as one representative of at least three repeated experiments. TZM-bl cells are a genetically engineered HeLa cell clone that express CD4, CCR5 and CXCR4. TZM-bl, 293 T, Vero and CEM174 cell lines were obtained from American Type Culture Collection. the cells were incubated at 37°C in a humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO2. 293 T cells were co-transfected with 6 g of an Env-deficient HIV-1 backbone vector (pSG3Env) and 4 g of a plasmid encoding envelope protein of one strain of HIV-1 subtype B. PV-containing cultures were harvested 48 h after transfection, centrifuged, purified by 0.45 m filter. culture medium was removed, monolayers were washed once with 200 l PBS. 100 l cell culture lysis buffer (Promega) was added to cells and incubated for 20 min at room temperature. samples producing relative light units (RLU)>2.5background wells (containing cells only) were scored as positive infection. imethylthiazol-2-yl)-5-(3-carboxymethoxyphenyl)-2-(4-sulfophenyl)-2H-tetrazolium (MTS) procedure. cells were seeded into 96-well plates at a density of 1104 cells/well. each dilution was tested in triplicates and all experiments were repeated three times. 50 of HIV-1 PV were incubated with indicated concentration of test scorpion venom peptides in a total volume of 100 l for 60 min. luciferase activities of the TZM-bl cells were measured for antiviral activities of tested peptides. virus control and blank control were set up as wells of cells plus virus and cells only respectively. samples were detected for p24 by ELISA and measured for infectivity by TZM-bl detection systems. four different treatment groups were designed to compare effects of peptide to viral infection. p24 protein detection by ELISA was used for p24 protein detection.
